questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive headache and neck pain for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had multiple episodes of dizziness and tingling sensations in his arms and hands. A year ago, he underwent closed reduction of a dislocated shoulder he sustained after a fall. He underwent surgical removal of a saclike protuberance on his lower back, soon after being born. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. His neck is supple. Neurological examination shows sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally and normal gross motor function. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastoma typically first manifests with increased intracranial pressure, which causes the classic triad of headaches, vomiting, and papilledema. Although subsequent hydrocephalus is common, medulloblastoma is not associated with syringomyelia or myelomeningocele. In addition, this patient's MRI shows dilated ventricles without evidence of a midline mass arising from the vermis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) manifests with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium. Extensive bleeding from IVH can also cause hydrocephalus. However, IVH occurs acutely rather than over the course of weeks. Moreover, imaging would show blood in the ventricles, which is not seen on the MRI.

C) INCORRECT:

Choroid plexus carcinoma is a rare malignant neoplasm of the choroid plexus that typically occurs in children < 5 years of age and can cause hydrocephalus. However, it is not associated with syringomyelia or meningomyelocele. Additionally, there are no visible tumors in the planes shown on MRI.

D) INCORRECT:

Dandy-Walker malformation is often associated with hydrocephalus, typically antenatally or in early infancy. Although it is possible for syringomyelia or myelomeningocele to occur in patients with Dandy-Walker malformation, such cases are extremely rare. Much more likely associations would be orofacial and cardiac defects, as well as intellectual and motor delay (especially with crawling and walking due to lack of cerebellar neurons), none of which are present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Chiari II malformation is characterized by the presence of myelomeningocele and caudal displacement of the vermis, tonsils, medulla, and fourth ventricle into the upper cervical canal. Caudal displacement can obstruct the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), causing it to accumulate either in the spinal cord, producing a syrinx, or in the cranium, resulting in hydrocephalus.

Patients most commonly present in childhood with evidence of hydrocephalus (e.g., headache, dizziness, papilledema) and/or syringomyelia (e.g., tingling of the arms and hands in this patient). This patient's MRI confirms hydrocephalus, and a sagittal view would show the malformation.

F) INCORRECT:

Vestibular schwannoma typically manifests with tinnitus, balance issues, and sensorineural hearing loss, the latter of which is the most common complaint. In very severe cases, they may grow large enough to cause headaches and brainstem compression, but they do not cause hydrocephalus or intracranial hypertension, nor would they occur over the course of two weeks. Although this patient has dizziness that could be explained by a schwannoma, it would not cause tingling in his arms or the observed optic disc swelling.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Tuberculous meningitis may manifest acutely or subacutely and has several cardinal features; fever, neck pain, and headache are early signs, progressing to confusion and coma in severe cases. Systemic manifestations, such as night sweats and weight loss, may also be observed. In some cases, collections of bacteria (tubercles) can become large enough to impede the typical flow of CSF in the cranium, leading to hydrocephalus. While this patient's MRI demonstrates hydrocephalus, the absence of other clinical findings (fever, systemic symptoms, neck pain) and clear risk factors for M. tuberculosis infection (e.g., immigration from an endemic area, pulmonary manifestations of TB) make this very unlikely. Also, there is no evidence of tubercles on this patient's MRI.

H) INCORRECT:

Shoulder dislocation and shoulder surgery are both risk factors for brachial plexus injury, which could cause acute unilateral arm tingling following a shoulder injury. This patient's symptoms are bilateral and occur one year after a shoulder injury, ruling out brachial plexus injury. In addition, injury of the brachial plexus would not explain this patient's other abnormalities.

I) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) classically manifests with an extraordinarily painful sudden onset headache (e.g., thunderclap headache). Vomiting and altered sensorium are also commonly observed. This patient developed symptoms over the course of two weeks and is not experiencing an intense headache, making SAH unlikely.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of hydrocephalus (headache, dizziness, papilledema, and dilated ventricles on MRI), syringomyelia (cape-like distribution of tingling in the upper extremities), and myelomeningocele (a saclike lesion on the lower back), all of which are characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive headaches, dizziness, and recurrent episodes of vomiting for 3 weeks. He has a history of surgical removal of a sac-like protuberance on his lower back soon after birth. Neurologic examination shows ataxia. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disk swelling. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chiari II malformation is characterized by a caudal displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils (with or without the medulla oblongata and the fourth ventricle) into the upper cervical canal. The displacement can obstruct the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and cause an accumulation of CSF within the spinal cord (producing a syrinx), or within the cranium (causing hydrocephalus). Patients often present in childhood with symptoms of hydrocephalus and resulting increased ICP. This patient's history of a sac-like protuberance on his lower back suggests spina bifida cystica, which is consistent with frequently associated lumbosacral myelomeningocele. The patient's MRI confirms the diagnosis of Chiari II malformation.

B) INCORRECT:

Chiari I malformation is characterized by the caudal displacement of cerebellar tonsils. While some patients may also develop symptoms of hydrocephalus, as seen in this patient, it typically also manifests with occipital headache, neck pain, lower cranial nerve palsies, a downbeat nystagmus, and radicular pain in the shoulders and arms, all of which are not present here. Moreover, it usually becomes symptomatic in adolescence/young adulthood, and a history of myelomeningocele is atypical for Chiari I malformation.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Low-lying cerebellar tonsils (green overlay) extend below the foramen magnum (white line) to C2-level and abut the medulla oblongata.

The finding is consistent with a Chiari I malformation. There is no evidence of a syrinx or hydrocephalus.

C) INCORRECT:

Ependymoma can present with signs of increased intracranial pressure, as seen in this patient. However, these tumors typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle, adapt to the shape of the ventricle, and extend through the foramina of Luschka and Magendi into the cisterns. It would be unusual for the tumor not to invade the ventricles and have cystic components on imaging, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, ependymoma would not explain this patient's history of lumbosacral myelomeningocele.

D) INCORRECT:

Dandy-Walker malformation is often associated with hydrocephalus, typically antenatally or early in infancy, which could explain this patient's findings of increased intracranial pressure. Although it is possible for myelomeningocele to occur in patients with Dandy-Walker malformation, such cases are extremely rare. Much more likely associations would be orofacial and cardiac defects, as well as intellectual and motor delay (especially with crawling and walking due to lack of cerebellar neurons), none of which are present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Vestibular schwannoma presents most commonly with sensorineural hearing loss and possibly also tinnitus and balance issues. Although in very severe cases, schwannomas may grow large enough to cause headaches and brainstem compression, they do not cause hydrocephalus, intracranial hypertension, or myelomeningocele, as observed in this patient, nor would these complications occur over the course of two weeks.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Choroid plexus carcinoma is a rare malignant neoplasm of the choroid plexus that typically occurs in children < 5 years and can cause hydrocephalus, which would manifest with findings of increased intracranial pressure as observed here. However, choroid plexus carcinoma is not associated with meningomyelocele. Additionally, at least in the plane shown, there are no visible tumors in the MRI.

G) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastoma is a common, aggressive pediatric intracranial neoplasm most commonly located in the cerebellar vermis. Initially, it typically manifests with the classic triad of morning headaches, vomiting, and fatigue due to increased intracranial pressure. Subsequent hydrocephalus is common and would produce symptoms of increased ICP as observed in this patient. However, medulloblastoma is not associated with myelomeningocele, which is suspected given the patient's history. Additionally, these MRI findings (e.g., inferiorly displaced cerebellar tonsils and vermis) suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: The MRI shows displacement of both the vermis and the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, which has likely caused an obstruction of the ventricular system. Symptoms like progressive headaches, dizziness, recurrent vomiting, abnormal gait, and papilledema suggest increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient's condition is almost always associated with a certain neural tube defect, which would explain the removal of the sac-like protuberance at the lower back soon after birth.
